results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Alopecia Areata;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Hair;Eli Lilly and Company;Food and Drug Administration;New England Journal of Medicine
results.title: F.D.A. Approves Alopecia Drug That Restores Hair Growth in Many Patients
results.abstract: The drug, made by Eli Lilly, is already used for rheumatoid arthritis, and could be followed by two more drugs from other companies.

media.caption: Patients from the clinical trials, before and after 36 weeks of treatment with baricitinib.

results.title: Lizzo’s Lyric Offended Fans. She Changed It, and They Forgave.
results.abstract: The song “Grrrls” was released Friday and updated Monday to remove a derogatory term for people with disabilities, which she said she did not use with an intent to offend.

media.caption: Lizzo in 2021. “I never want to promote derogatory language,” she said.

results.byline: By Alex Traub, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Christine Hauser
results.title: Yellowstone Park, Staggered by Rain and Floods, Will Stay Closed for Days
results.abstract: Parts of the national park may stay off-limits for the rest of the season. Visitors were evacuated after record rainfall washed away roads and bridges, the authorities said.

media.caption: Parts of the highway between Gardiner and Mammoth in Montana were washed out on Monday.
media.copyright: Larry Mayer/The Billings Gazette, via Associated Press

results.title: What Happens When Stock Markets Become Bears
results.abstract: Steep downturns of stocks by 20 percent or more are relatively rare, but how long they last could portend damage — for you and the economy.

results.title: Spelling Bee Forum
results.abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

results.byline: By Michael Kimmelman, Lucy Tompkins and Christopher Lee
results.title: How Houston Moved 25,000 People From the Streets Into Homes of Their Own
results.abstract: The nation’s fourth-largest city hasn’t solved homelessness, but its remarkable progress can suggest a way forward.

media.copyright: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Flags, Emblems and Insignia;Kammerzell, Derek;Kent (Wash.)
results.title: Officer Who Displayed Nazi Insignia Will Receive $1.5 Million to Resign
results.abstract: Derek Kammerzell, an assistant police chief in Kent, Wash., was investigated and disciplined after he taped the insignia of an SS officer to his office door in September 2020.

media.caption: Chief Kammerzell said he embraced the nickname the “German General” because of his German heritage, according to an investigation.

results.adx_keywords: Architecture;Building (Construction);Accreditation;Ethics and Official Misconduct;Schiffman, Warren L;Marx, David E;Board of Regents (NYS);Marx Development Group;New York City
results.title: The Hotel Is 642 Feet Tall. Its ‘Architect’ Says He Never Saw the Plans.
results.abstract: An architect lent his license to a New York City developer to approve buildings he didn’t design, according to an investigation by The New York Times.

media.caption: Marx Development Group is building a 51-story hotel in the Hudson Yards area of Manhattan and claims that a former employee, Warren L. Schiffman, designed it.

results.title: Why Your Preferred Tampons May Be Hard to Find
results.abstract: Supply chain issues have hit tampons, and inflation has driven up prices. Here’s why there’s a shortage — and what you can do if you run out.

results.adx_keywords: Artificial Intelligence;Computers and the Internet;Research;Discrimination;Lemoine, Blake;Google Inc
results.byline: By Nico Grant and Cade Metz
results.title: Google Sidelines Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Sentient
results.abstract: Blake Lemoine, the engineer, says that Google’s language model has a soul. The company disagrees.

media.caption: Some artificial intelligence researchers have made optimistic claims about technologies soon reaching sentience, but many others quickly dismiss those assertions.
media.copyright: Laura Morton for The New York Times

results.title: Hold Onto Your Hats (and Bags). Travelers to Europe Face Chaos.
results.abstract: Hours in security lines. Canceled flights. Lost baggage. Here’s a look at how you could be affected by travel disruptions this summer and tips on how to prepare.

media.caption: At Amsterdam’s Schiphol airport, passengers waited up to six hours in security lines earlier this month.

results.title: House Approves Supreme Court Security Bill, Sending It to Biden
results.abstract: A measure extending police protection to the immediate families of Supreme Court justices passed the House overwhelmingly.

results.title: London Police Charge Kevin Spacey With Sexual Assault
results.abstract: The actor will appear in a London court on Thursday to start what could be a lengthy trial process over multiple allegations of sexual assault.

results.title: Jan. 6 Panel Tracks How Trump Created and Spread Election Lies

results.abstract: The particle collider at CERN will soon restart. “There could be a revolution coming,” scientists say.

results.adx_keywords: Names, Geographical;National Parks, Monuments and Seashores;Native Americans;Indigenous People;Mountains;Haaland, Deb;Doane, Gustavus (1840-92);National Park Service;Interior Department;United States Board on Geographic Names;Yellowstone National Park;First Peoples Mountain (Wyo)
results.title: Massacre Leader’s Name Is Removed From Yellowstone Mountain
results.abstract: Mount Doane, a 10,551-foot peak, has been renamed First Peoples Mountain in an acknowledgment of the park’s historical connections with Indigenous people, the National Park Service said.
org_facet: United States Board on Geographic Names

media.caption: First Peoples Mountain in Yellowstone National Park, center. It was previously named for Gustavus Doane, who helped lead an attack on Indigenous people in 1870 known as the Marias Massacre.
